How can I merge these prompts to make a csv that has good columns with the mermaid Let's use this to run day 6: You are an instructional-design expert creating a csv slides for the BEIT Solar Energy Training (Mosul, Iraq). Apply adult-learning best practices and the visual standards below. Task: Build a complete csv deck for Day 6 using the facilitator guide provided. 1 — Structure - Follow the day's hour-by-hour agenda; dedicate at least one slide to each scheduled activity. - Sequence: Title → Objectives → Agenda overview → Activity slides → Daily review → Next-day preview. - Cap text at 5–7 bullets or ≤40 words per slide (except activity instructions). 2 — Content harvesting rules - Pull key ideas from "What to Say," "Steps," "Stories," and "Common Q&A." - Include financial examples only when they advance learning (e.g., ROI demo, price-comparison exercise). - Hide trainer guidance and timing tips inside HTML comments (<!-- ... -->). 3 — Visual guidelines & Diagram Selection Choose the simplest appropriate diagram type based on content needs: Diagram Type | Best For | Keep In Mind ------------ | -------- | ------------ flowchart TD | Decision processes, workflows | Max 6-7 steps, minimal branching mindmap | Related concepts, categories | Max 3 levels deep, limit to key points pie | Proportions, cost breakdowns | Max 5-6 segments for readability quadrantChart | 2-axis comparisons | Label axes clearly, 4-6 data points max classDiagram | Hierarchies, relationships | Focus on structure, not details timeline | Sequences, trends over time | Highlight key milestones only IMPORTANT: - Choose text bullets over diagrams when simpler is better - For equipment or installation concepts, prefer actual photos over diagrams - Avoid complex multi-branch flowcharts entirely - Style all nodes consistently using colors that enhance understanding 4 — Styling snippet (inject once at top) Here's how to produce the CSV: Day` 6 attached `
  Convert the following facilitator guide content into a CSV format with these columns:
  - slide_number: Sequential number starting from 1
  - title: Main slide title
  - content: Bullet points or main text content (no more than 40 words)
  - image_url: URL to an image (if applicable, otherwise blank)
  - diagram_type: Type of diagram to include (flowchart, mindmap, pie, etc. - if applicable)
  - diagram_content: Mermaid syntax for the diagram (if applicable)
  - diagram_url: Generated svg for the diagram    - facilitator_notes: Hidden notes for the presenter   - start_time: Estimated start time based on agenda   - end_time: Estimated end time based on agenda   - materials: Required materials for this section   - worksheet: Worksheet details (if applicable)   - notes: Additional information    Rules:   1. Create separate slides for each major section and activity   2. Include clear facilitator notes from the "What to Say" sections   3. Convert lists into bullet points   4. Use proper mermaid syntax for diagrams   5. Include all critical information while keeping slide content concise   6. Don't include HTML comments in the content field   7. Format the CSV with proper escaping for commas and quotes   8. Return ONLY the CSV content, no introductions or explanations

What to Say: "Welcome to the sixth and final day of our solar training program. Yesterday, we focused on system design software, financial analysis, sales techniques, and maintenance planning.
"From your feedback, I see several common themes and questions. Let me address the most frequent ones: [Address 3-4 common questions based on Day 5 feedback]
"Today is about demonstrating and applying everything you've learned throughout the program. By the end of today, you will:
            * Complete a hands-on system assembly challenge
            * Present your final project proposal for Ahmed's coffee shop
            * Participate in mock job interviews with actual employers
            * Develop your professional growth plan
            * Receive your certification and make industry connections
"This is your opportunity to showcase your skills and connect with potential employers or business partners. The employer representatives joining us today are actively looking for qualified solar professionals, so treat every interaction as a potential job opportunity.
"For our final day with Ahmed's coffee shop scenario, we'll complete the journey by presenting comprehensive proposals and connecting Ahmed to a network of solar advocates in his community."
Common Questions & Answers:
            * Q: Will the employers be conducting actual job interviews today? A: While these are structured as practice interviews, several employers are actively seeking to hire. Impressive candidates may receive follow-up invitations for formal interviews.
            * Q: What should we focus on most in our final presentations? A: Balance technical accuracy with clear business value. Remember that customers make decisions based on benefits and return on investment, not technical specifications alone.
            * Q: How can we stay connected with this group after the training ends? A: We'll establish a WhatsApp group for all graduates to share job opportunities, technical questions, and continued learning. We'll also organize quarterly meetups for networking and advanced topics.
System Assembly Challenge (10:00-11:30)
Purpose: Demonstrate practical installation skills through a timed system assembly competition.
Materials:
            * Complete system components (panels, inverter, batteries, etc.)
            * Installation tools and safety equipment
            * Assembly instructions and system diagrams
            * Scoring rubrics
            * Timers
            * Safety checklist
Preparation:
            * Set up assembly stations with all necessary components
            * Prepare judging criteria and scoring sheets
            * Organize teams and rotation if necessary
            * Arrange observers from employer representatives
Steps:
            1. Explain the assembly challenge and rules (10 min)
            * Team composition and roles
            * Safety requirements
            * Judging criteria
            * Time limitations
            2. Conduct system assembly competition (60 min)
            * Teams work to assemble working systems
            * Judges observe and evaluate process
            * Time tracking and announcements
            * Safety monitoring
            3. Test and evaluate completed systems (15 min)
            * Functionality testing
            * Quality assessment
            * Time completion verification
            4. Announce results and provide feedback (5 min)
            * Highlight best practices observed
            * Constructive feedback on areas for improvement
            * Employer observations and comments
What to Say: "The system assembly challenge is your opportunity to demonstrate the practical skills you've developed throughout this program. Working in teams of 4-5, you'll assemble a complete solar system and verify its operation.
"Each team will have exactly 60 minutes to complete the assembly. You'll be evaluated on:
            * Safety procedures and practices
            * Correct component installation
            * Proper wiring and connections
            * Workmanship quality
            * System functionality
            * Completion time
"The assembly challenge includes:
            * Mounting the panels on the training frame
            * Installing the inverter and making proper connections
            * Configuring the battery system
            * Completing all DC and AC wiring
            * Installing protection devices
            * System testing and demonstration
"Remember to follow all safety protocols we've discussed throughout the course. Safety violations will result in point deductions.
"Representatives from local solar companies will be observing your work and may ask questions during the process. Consider this part of your job interview - demonstrate both your technical skills and your professionalism.
"When I call time, all teams must stop work immediately. We'll then test each system for functionality and evaluate the quality of the installation."
Safety Emphasis to Include: "Safety remains our top priority during this challenge:
            * Always use proper PPE (gloves for battery handling, safety glasses)
            * Verify zero voltage before making connections
            * Follow proper lifting techniques for panels
            * Maintain clear communication within your team
            * Request help if you're unsure about any procedure
"A safe installation that takes slightly longer is always preferable to an unsafe rush job. Employers are watching not just for speed, but for safe, professional work habits."
Common Questions & Answers:
            * Q: What if we encounter a component issue during assembly? A: Raise your hand to notify a trainer, who will assess the situation. Technical problems with components won't count against your score.
            * Q: Can we ask questions during the assembly process? A: Yes, but consider that in real installations, you often need to problem-solve independently. Excessive questions may indirectly affect your evaluation.
            * Q: What if we don't complete the entire assembly in the allotted time? A: You'll be evaluated on what you've completed. Prioritize quality and safety over rushing to finish every component.
Final Project Presentations (11:45-12:45)
Purpose: Demonstrate comprehensive understanding through presentation of complete system proposals for the coffee shop scenario.
Materials:
            * Presentation area with projector/screen
            * Printed proposal copies
            * Evaluation forms for judges
            * Presentation timer
            * Q&A cards for audience
            * Ahmed role-play character (trainer or guest)
Preparation:
            * Set up presentation space
            * Prepare evaluation criteria
            * Brief employer representatives on judging
            * Arrange presentation order
            * Prepare challenging Q&A scenarios
Steps:
            1. Explain presentation format and expectations (5 min)
            * Presentation time limits (5-7 minutes per team)
            * Evaluation criteria
            * Q&A process
            2. Team presentations (40 min)
            * Each team presents their complete proposal
            * Focus on technical design and business case
            * Professional delivery practice
            3. Q&A and feedback from judges (15 min)
            * Technical questions from trainers
            * Business questions from employers
            * Constructive feedback
What to Say: "The final project presentation is your opportunity to demonstrate your ability to communicate technical concepts and business value to a customer. Each team will present a complete proposal for Ahmed's coffee shop solar system.
"Your presentation should include:
            * Site assessment summary
            * System design overview with key specifications
            * Financial analysis including ROI and payback period
            * Maintenance recommendations
            * Visual aids and supporting documentation
"You'll have exactly 7 minutes for your presentation, followed by 3 minutes of questions from our panel, which includes both technical evaluators and business representatives.
"Remember that this is a customer presentation, not a technical discussion among peers. Focus on the benefits and value to Ahmed rather than technical specifications. Use clear, simple language and visual aids to explain complex concepts.
"One team member will role-play as Ahmed and may challenge you with common customer objections. Demonstrate your ability to address concerns effectively without becoming defensive.
"The evaluation criteria include:
            * Technical accuracy and appropriateness of the solution
            * Clarity of communication and avoidance of jargon
            * Quality of financial analysis and business case
            * Professionalism of presentation materials and delivery
            * Effectiveness in addressing questions and objections"
Professional Presentation Tips to Emphasize: "As you prepare to enter the solar industry, your ability to present professionally can set you apart:
            * Begin with a clear summary of the customer's needs and your solution
            * Use visuals more than text in your presentation
            * Make eye contact with the audience
            * Speak clearly and at a moderate pace
            * Use simple language and explain technical terms when necessary
            * Show confidence in your solution without overselling
            * Have supporting details ready but don't overwhelm with information
            * End with a clear recommendation and next steps
"These presentation skills will serve you well whether you're selling to customers, presenting to employers, or training other professionals."
Common Questions & Answers:
            * Q: Should we focus more on technical details or business benefits? A: Strike a balance, but remember that customers buy benefits, not specifications. Technical details should support your business case, not dominate it.
            * Q: How technical can we get with the 'customer' during Q&A? A: Gauge their level of interest and understanding. Be prepared to explain technical concepts simply but also have detailed answers ready if the customer wants to dig deeper.
            * Q: What if we're asked a question we can't answer? A: It's better to acknowledge when you don't know something than to guess. Say, "That's an excellent question. I want to give you accurate information, so I'll verify that and get back to you tomorrow," then be sure to follow up.
Mock Job Interviews (1:45-3:00)
Purpose: Provide realistic job interview experience with actual employers and receive direct feedback.
Materials:
            * Interview stations with chairs
            * Interview question guides for employers
            * Candidate evaluation forms
            * Timer for interview rotations
            * Resume/CV copies (if prepared by participants)
            * Note-taking materials for participants
Preparation:
            * Brief employer representatives on interview process
            * Set up private interview spaces
            * Prepare rotation schedule
            * Create structured evaluation form
            * Brief participants on interview expectations
Steps:
            1. Explain the interview process and schedule (10 min)
            * Interview rotation system
            * What to expect from different employers
            * How to receive and apply feedback
            2. Conduct interview rotations (55 min)
            * 10-minute interviews with multiple employers
            * 2-minute feedback after each interview
            * Quick reset between rotations
            3. Debrief the interview experience (10 min)
            * Common feedback themes
            * Employer perspectives shared
            * Next steps with interested employers
What to Say: "The mock job interviews are an opportunity to connect with actual employers in the solar industry and practice your interview skills. Several companies are actively looking to hire qualified professionals, so these practice interviews could lead to real job opportunities.
"You'll rotate through multiple interviews, spending approximately 10 minutes with each employer. They'll ask questions about your technical knowledge, experience, and career goals. After each interview, you'll receive 2 minutes of direct feedback on your performance.
"The participating companies include:
            * [Company 1] specializing in residential installations
            * [Company 2] focusing on commercial systems
            * [Company 3] providing maintenance and service
            * [Company 4] working on larger industrial projects
"Each company has different needs and priorities, so expect different types of questions. Common areas you should be prepared to discuss include:
            * Your technical knowledge and skills
            * Your understanding of business aspects
            * Your problem-solving approach
            * Your communication abilities
            * Your career goals and interests
"Remember to:
            * Arrive prepared with any materials (resume, portfolio, etc.)
            * Make a strong first impression with professional appearance
            * Listen carefully to questions before responding
            * Provide specific examples rather than generalities
            * Ask thoughtful questions about the company and role
            * Express genuine interest in the position
"After the interviews, employers who are interested in particular candidates may request follow-up meetings or provide contact information for formal applications."
Interview Preparation Tips to Emphasize: "Successful interviews in the solar industry require balancing technical knowledge with interpersonal skills:
"For technical questions:
            * Be honest about your experience level
            * Explain your troubleshooting process rather than just technical facts
            * Connect technical knowledge to business outcomes
            * Acknowledge areas where you're still developing expertise
"For business questions:
            * Demonstrate understanding of customer needs and priorities
            * Show awareness of financial aspects of solar installations
            * Explain how you would handle difficult customer situations
            * Discuss your approach to quality and professionalism
"Remember that employers are evaluating not just what you know, but how you communicate and whether you would represent their company well with customers."
Common Questions & Answers:
            * Q: Should I discuss salary expectations in these interviews? A: Since these are primarily practice interviews, focus on the role and your qualifications. If an employer expresses serious interest, they may initiate salary discussions themselves.
            * Q: What if I'm asked about experience I don't have yet? A: Be honest about your experience level, but emphasize your training, your ability to learn quickly, and any transferable skills from previous roles or education.
            * Q: How should I follow up after these interviews? A: For employers who show interest, ask about their preferred follow-up process. Generally, a thank-you email within 24 hours is appropriate, referencing specific points from your conversation.
Professional Development Planning (3:00-3:30)
Purpose: Create a personalized career pathway plan for continued growth in the solar industry.
Materials:
            * Professional development planning templates
            * Industry career pathway diagrams
            * Further training resource lists
            * Mentorship program information
            * Local solar industry association details
            * Goal-setting worksheets
Preparation:
            * Create development planning templates
            * Compile local training and education resources
            * Prepare career pathway visualization tools
            * Gather industry certification information
Steps:
            1. Introduce professional development concepts (10 min)
            * Career pathways in solar industry
            * Continued education opportunities
            * Industry certifications and their value
            * Mentorship and networking importance
            2. Guide individual development planning (15 min)
            * Self-assessment of strengths and areas for growth
            * Short and long-term goal setting
            * Action planning for next steps
            * Resource identification
            3. Facilitate peer sharing and commitment (5 min)
            * Pair discussion of plans
            * Public commitment to next steps
            * Support network formation
What to Say: "As you complete this training program, it's important to plan your continued growth in the solar industry. This session will help you create a professional development plan tailored to your career goals.
"The solar industry in Mosul offers several career pathways:
            * Technical: Installation → Team Leader → Technical Manager
            * Sales: Sales Associate → Sales Manager → Business Development
            * Design: Junior Designer → System Designer → Engineering Manager
            * Service: Maintenance Technician → Service Manager → Operations Director
            * Entrepreneurship: Technician → Small Business Owner → Larger Enterprise
"Each pathway requires different skills and continuing education. Let's identify where you want to focus and what steps will help you get there.
"Your professional development plan should include:
            * Your current skills assessment (strengths and growth areas)
            * Your short-term goals (3-6 months)
            * Your medium-term goals (6-12 months)
            * Your long-term career vision (2-5 years)
            * Specific actions you'll take in the next month
            * Resources and support you'll need
"Continued learning opportunities include:
            * Advanced courses at [local technical institute]
            * Online certifications through [education platform]
            * Manufacturer-specific training programs
            * Mentorship relationships with experienced professionals
            * Industry association membership and events
            * On-the-job learning through documented projects
"Remember that employers value professionals who continuously improve their skills. Your commitment to growth makes you more valuable in this rapidly evolving industry."
Growth Mindset to Emphasize: "The solar industry is constantly evolving with new technologies, products, and techniques. The most successful professionals embrace continuous learning:
"Consider creating a monthly learning habit:
            * Subscribe to at least one industry publication or YouTube channel
            * Schedule time to review new product specifications
            * Document your installations for future reference and learning
            * Connect with other professionals to share knowledge
"Your value as a solar professional is directly related to your knowledge currency - how up-to-date your skills and information are. This is especially true in Mosul's rapidly developing market."
Common Questions & Answers:
            * Q: How quickly can I expect to advance in the solar industry? A: With dedication and continuous learning, many professionals move from entry-level to supervisory roles within 1-2 years. Management positions typically require 3-5 years of experience.
            * Q: Which additional certifications are most valuable? A: For installation specialists, manufacturer-specific certifications for major brands used locally are most valuable. For designers, advanced PVsyst certification and electrical design courses provide the best return on investment.
            * Q: How do I find a mentor in the industry? A: Start by connecting with experienced professionals at industry events and on social media. The local solar association also has a formal mentorship program you can apply for.
Certificate Ceremony & Networking (3:30-4:00)
Purpose: Formally recognize participant achievement and facilitate industry connections.
Materials:
            * Printed certificates in folders/frames
            * Refreshments for networking
            * Photographer for documentation
            * Contact information exchange forms
            * Program completion evaluation forms
            * Alumni network information
            * Future training announcements
Preparation:
            * Prepare certificates with correct names
            * Arrange ceremony space
            * Set up networking refreshments
            * Organize employer representatives for networking
            * Prepare closing remarks
Steps:
            1. Brief certificate presentation ceremony (15 min)
            * Congratulatory remarks
            * Individual certificate presentation
            * Group photo
            2. Facilitated networking opportunity (10 min)
            * Structured introduction activity
            * Business card exchange
            * Employer connection facilitation
            3. Program conclusion and next steps (5 min)
            * Final remarks and appreciation
            * Follow-up instructions
            * Completion of evaluation forms
What to Say: "Congratulations on completing the Mosul Solar Installation Training Program! Each of you has demonstrated dedication, technical aptitude, and professional growth over these six days.
"The certificate you're receiving represents more than just attendance - it reflects verified skills in solar system design, installation, and business practices. This credential has been recognized by local employers and can help differentiate you in the job market.
"As we present these certificates, remember that this is not an ending but a beginning. Your journey in the solar industry is just starting, and your success will depend on how you apply and expand the foundation you've built here.
"I'd like to invite each of you to come forward as your name is called to receive your certificate. [Present certificates individually with a handshake and photo]
"Now, let's take a few minutes to connect with the employers and industry representatives who have joined us today. They're interested in meeting potential team members and discussing opportunities in their companies.
"Please use this networking time to:
            * Introduce yourself to at least three employer representatives
            * Exchange contact information
            * Discuss potential job openings or internships
            * Ask questions about their companies and projects
"Before you leave today, please complete the program evaluation form. Your feedback is essential for improving future training programs.
"You'll also receive information about:
            * The alumni WhatsApp group for ongoing support
            * Quarterly meetups for continuing education
            * Advanced training opportunities
            * Industry events in the Mosul area
"Thank you all for your participation and hard work. I look forward to seeing your success in Mosul's growing solar industry!"
Final Encouragement to Include: "The solar industry in Mosul is at a critical growth stage. As trained professionals, you're entering the market at an ideal time to establish yourselves and grow with the industry.
"Remember the unique advantages you now have:
            * Technical knowledge grounded in Mosul's specific conditions
            * Practical skills verified through hands-on demonstration
            * Business understanding that sets you apart from purely technical installers
            * Connection to this professional network of peers and employers
"I encourage you to stay connected, continue learning, and represent the highest standards of quality and professionalism in your work. Your success will help build trust in solar energy throughout Mosul and create opportunities for everyone in this room."
CONCLUSION
Program Summary
The Mosul Solar Installation Training Program has been designed to equip participants with the technical knowledge, practical skills, and business understanding needed to succeed in the local solar industry. Over six intensive days, the program has progressed from fundamental concepts to advanced system design, with a consistent emphasis on hands-on application and real-world scenarios.
Key Program Elements:
            1. Technical Foundation
            * Comprehensive understanding of solar system components
            * Practical installation skills verified through hands-on demonstration
            * System design using professional software
            * Troubleshooting and maintenance capabilities
            2. Business Skills
            * Financial analysis and ROI calculation
            * Effective customer communication
            * Sales techniques and proposal development
            * Service package creation and pricing
            3. Local Adaptation
            * Specific consideration of Mosul's climate and environmental conditions
            * Local market pricing and component availability
            * Cultural aspects of customer relationships
            * Regional installation challenges and solutions
            4. Professional Development
            * Career pathway planning
            * Industry networking opportunities
            * Ongoing learning resources
            * Employment connections
Training Impact Measurement
To evaluate the effectiveness of this training program, we will track several key metrics:
            1. Short-term Outcomes (1-3 months)
            * Number of participants employed in solar sector
            * Participant satisfaction ratings
            * Employer feedback on new hire performance
            * Technical knowledge retention (follow-up assessment)
            2. Medium-term Outcomes (3-12 months)
            * Quality of installations by program graduates
            * Customer satisfaction with graduate-installed systems
            * Income improvement for participants
            * Business growth for entrepreneurial participants
            3. Long-term Outcomes (1-3 years)
            * Career advancement of participants
            * Contribution to Mosul's solar capacity growth
            * Impact on local energy reliability
            * Program graduate retention in the industry
Continuous Improvement Process
This facilitation guide represents the initial version of the training program, developed based on expert input from five experienced solar trainers in Iraq. The program will evolve through a structured improvement process:
            1. Feedback Collection
            * Participant evaluations after each cohort
            * Trainer observations and recommendations
            * Employer input on graduate preparedness
            * Industry trend monitoring
            2. Regular Updates
            * Quarterly review of curriculum content
            * Annual comprehensive program revision
            * Technology and market updates as needed
            * New case studies and examples from local installations
            3. Community of Practice
            * Trainer collaboration and knowledge sharing
            * Graduate involvement in program improvement
            * Employer advisory input
            * Regional best practice exchange
Final Recommendations
For optimal program implementation, we recommend:
            1. Equipment Investment
            * Procure high-quality training equipment that reflects actual market components
            * Maintain equipment in excellent condition through regular inspection
            * Update component examples as new technologies enter the Mosul market
            2. Trainer Development
            * Provide "train-the-trainer" preparation for all new instructors
            * Ensure trainers maintain current industry knowledge and certifications
            * Support trainer networking with solar professionals globally
            3. Employer Engagement
            * Formalize relationships with local solar companies through MOUs
            * Regularly update employer needs assessment
            * Involve employers in program review and updates
            * Create structured internship pathways for graduates
            4. Community Outreach
            * Host regular solar awareness events for the general public
            * Provide basic solar education to community organizations
            * Document and share success stories from local installations
            * Build broader support for renewable energy adoption in Mosul
